title: Downton Abbey review: it's a higher-budget extended-length episode for the fans
text:
Writer/creator Julian Fellows has done a good job weaving all the different characters’ storylines together in a deft and enjoyable way. Again, he’s experienced at this, but there are so many plates to spin here, especially with the newcomers on board too (Tuppence Middleton and Imelda Staunton to name but two) and while at times it feels like one very long, very posh montage – cooking food, getting changed, going to a ball, fixing the boiler, going to a parade – it’s all so slick and polished it ticks along nicely.

This is pure “conservative with a small c” escapism: a warm, old-fashioned, cuddly jumper hug of a movie where nothing is too challenging and everyone gets along (more or less). It’s been put together for the legions of fans who are hankering for more from their favourite show, and it delivers just that. Here’s the higher-budget extended-length episode that you can watch with your friends in the cinema, and if you enjoy the series, you’ll enjoy this. That said, again, as a total newcomer, I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed it despite the lack of prior knowledge. It’s nice, it’s pretty, it’s witty, it’s Downton.

Cons

That said, I would have benefitted from a glance at a family tree to work out who is who and who is related to whom, and who is in love with whom, and all that sort of practical stuff. It’s fine, like I say, and I admire the filmmakers for realising that they’re making a product “for the fans” and in so doing resisting the urge to over explain things for the benefit of the newbies, but a quick look at Wikipedia would have made a difference I must say.
